comments.text:
Religion *had* a basis in reality. It was built as a web of organization 
that held together the bits and pieces of knowledge available at the time 
in a way that was understandable to the average person of the time. Not 
unlike we describe cutting edge scientific concepts today. As far as I 
understand, atoms and their electrons don't actually resemble a tiny solar 
system, but it is an effective descriptor. And the analogies used to 
describe quantum physics theories are necessarily less than perfect. Should 
the populations of the year 4000 cling to our narratives of those concepts, 
in spite of what the more refined understanding scientists of their time 
will have attained, we might be looked upon in the same way we look back 
upon the origins of religion. And rightly so. I mean to specifically point 
to the long forgotten creators and tellers of such tales that have long 
slipped from history, and probably crafter those tales in our era of 
tribes, long before even what it had become 2000 years ago. 
Comparatively, those people probably had the knowledge a 3 year old has 
now. About the more abstract things we must learn from others and not the 
very limited first-hand knowledge we gain. 
I find it all terribly fascinating to think about, having learned enough 
about psychology and communication theory for me to see the valid origin of 
religion. 
What you see above is a snapshot of an ancient time, decayed from 
generation to generation, all the way back to tribes and even beyond. 
Clinging feebly onto a memory of a memory of a memory of a memory... beyond 
any resemblance of what was then, or what is now. 

Nothing comes from nothingness. Order does inevitably come from "pure" 
chaos though, just in relatively tiny little pockets. Really really tiny. 
No bigger than a universe. :-)

comments.author: Philip McCorkle

comments.text:
+Philip McCorkle I'm sorry you think that it is a well-reasoned idea to 
terminate all pregnancies with the "slightest genetic defect" and to force 
the sterilization of individuals with genetic defects. In fact, it is a 
failure to reason, and a lack of knowledge of genetics, which would lead a 
person to such beliefs.

Yes, all morality is derived through reason. From where else is any 
knowledge of any kind derived? Unreason? Illogic? Arbitrary assumptions?

Empathy and reason can find themselves at odds. (Humans are naturally 
susceptible to having disproportionate empathy for those of their own 
family, for example, even when those family members behave in ways that 
harm other people.) But more often than not, being empathetic makes it 
easier to reason correctly.

Even setting empathy aside, however; even setting aside the fact that while 
certain mutations are maladaptive, offshoots of those mutations may have 
great benefit, and that it is thus generally beneficial to preserve as much 
diversity in the human gene pool as possible; eugenics is *still* 
unreasonable. It is quite reasonable to come to the conclusion, based only 
on what we know about people and how they view their freedom to carry 
through their pregnancies how they see fit, that the dystopian social cost 
of eugenics outweighs any possible benefit that artificial selection would 
provide.

We're not asking the question, "What stops *any* person of faith from being 
evil?" Rather, we are asking the question, "What stops a particular person 
of faith -- a person who believes that having faith is the only reason not 
to be evil -- from being evil if they lose their faith?"

It really isn't complicated. Such people aren't arguing that their systems 
of moral beliefs are in addition to mine -- they are arguing that mine do 
not exist; and, that theirs wouldn't either the moment they stopped 
believing in God.

my years) usually claim that morality derives from their religion and many 
claim it comes from the bible.  However, this attitude opens up the door 
not too dissimilar from the view portrayed by Cruz - i.e. that only their 
particular religious flavor of morality is correct.  It begs the question 
about morality of people in other religions as well as those of athiests. 
 Clearly, it is silly to state that only christians have morals. Societies 
function across the spectra of religious and cultural beliefs and societies 
were certainly able to function prior to the development of christianity or 
any of the Abrahamic religions.  Alternatively, if christian's allow 
morality to be sourced from outside religion, which the evidence surely 
indicates, then it begs the question of what real purpose does their 
religion provide to society.  In the latter case, religion can be 
denigrated to a social club or relegated in value only at the individual 
level of one seeking commune with their spiritual side.  Organized religion 
is hardly a necessity for the latter.

top_comment.text:
Cenk and other atheists who claim that they are "inherently moral" are full 
of shit, and they know it. Most humans are only as "moral" as their 
circumstances and will earnestly throw their morality out the window if it 
means assuring their survival or personal interest. An atheist starving to 
death would not hesitate to steal a piece of meat, or rob someone of their 
food, and in extreme circumstances, may even resort to cannibalism. Of 
course most people would sacrifice themselves to save a loved one or close 
friend but that is still a self interested act because our loved ones and 
close friend are part of who we are. How many would be willing to sacrifice 
themselves for complete strangers? Maybe 10% of the people if we are being 
generous? Please, the only thing inherent in us is the instinct for 
survival and that trumps all our lofty ideas and moral principals any day. 
So the next time Dawkins or someone else tells you that "morality is 
inherent in humans" or the product of "human evolution" just remember "its 
bullshit and its bad for you." ﻿
top_comment.author: Plato86

comments.text:
Btw I think you made some good points. Don't completely agree with you 
completely but rational all the same. I've always believed that people are 
generally good, but that's it's a result of society, not any inbuilt 
morals. Ethics are entirely human, no doubt about it, but I do think you 
might be underestimating their basis in behavioral evolution. Take rearing 
of young. Humans can rationalise and philosophise our attachment to our 
young, but it's an inherently mammalian instinct. If a sapient species had 
evolved from most reptiles, it's unlikely their society would have such a 
moral norm for nurturing and protecting their young.
comments.author: Calum Thomas

comments.text:
You seem to be confusing morals with Altruism/egoism. Any action, even the 
noblest, can be seen as selfish, but that doesn't make it immoral. Charity 
is a good example. I'm sure a lot of people give to charity because it 
makes them feel good about themselves. That doesn't make it a bad thing. 
Survival is the key defining instinct of every animal, that is true, but 
that doesn't always mean individual survival. Many animals behave in 
manners which may not be beneficial for their own survival, or sometimes 
even the survival of their own genetic pool, but behaviors that promote the 
survival of the species as a whole.
comments.author: Calum Thomas

comments.text:
Humans are unique creatures that think about the future.  Humans are able 
to experience selfless feelings because their brain rewards them 
psychologically for being good.  Morality is both influenced by logic and 
emotion.  When I donate money to a good cause, the only thing I gain is the 
thought of helping someone out, even though I did it anonymously and would 
gain nothing material or reputable in return.  In rationality, I know that 
if the charity does what it says, the money will go to people whom I pity 
and make their living easier.
Also, have you ever seen how the average person reacts when they hold a 
Furbie(?) upside-down.  They feel uneasy at "scaring" it even though it is 
just a toy.

Morality would break down anywhere for anyone if there was scarcity.  
Atheists will most likely only be slightly quicker at best compared to 
others.  Every human has their price.
